caption: This museum is a hidden gem, offering one of the most captivating experiences in Paris. It delves into the art of coin craftsmanship and the evolution of metalwork over time. The collection includes coins from ancient Greece, Rome, and modern eras. Beyond coins and ingots, you‚Äôll discover fascinating stories, such as the recovery of treasures from a sunken Dutch ship. Visitors can also explore the impressive coin-printing machines in action.  Ideal for families, friends, or anyone seeking a unique activity, this museum offers a relaxed experience without the long queues typical of Parisian attractions. Conveniently located near the Louvre, it‚Äôs a perfect addition to your visit.
Very beautiful building next to Seine River.  This year. The place hosted the 10th anniversary of Asia Now exhibition Art Paris.
I visited here a few years ago. The exhibition was great, as was the museum building itself.

I visited the museum for free because it was the free weekend so it was a bit crowded but still need to book ticket. I was given coins to carve at the beginning of the tour Displays were nice but a bit too technical at the beginning

We've been visiting the Museum on August 23 for the permanent exhibition and also temporary exhibition featuring Money in the Art. Famous and iconic subjects are on display in this museum covering more than millennial operation of coin minting in France. I particularly loved the items on consumerism in the Art.

We had a really good time visiting the Minnie de Paris Museum, specifically the Arcade exhibit that had vintage video and pinball machines that you could play.  If you purchased entry to the exhibit online, they gave you 12 tokens to play the games.  Some of the machines were free to play (at the front of the exhibit).  It was a lot of fun to go back in time to play machines that I knew when they first came out.  Even more fun to be able to play with my kids.  My only encounter with someone rude in France happened here, however.  There were lineups to play and everyone was waiting patiently‚Ä¶ except one individual behind me who took exception to the fact that one of my kids and I were quite good on one machine‚Ä¶ and had a fit like a 2 yr old because she had to wait.  Luckily my French is limited so I couldn‚Äôt understand her‚Ä¶ so it didn‚Äôt bother me.  Besides that, everyone else that we encountered in Paris was great - happy, helpful and pretty cool.
Awesome place. So much history here. Need to visit.
Very fascinating museum about all forms of currency. Also, special exhibits could be available  for viewing. It gives glimpses into how money is produced both past and present.

A numismatic paradise in the heart of Paris  The Mus√©e de la Monnaie is a treasure trove of history and art that any coin or medal enthusiast would be thrilled to discover. From the moment you step into the elegant building, you are transported to a world of intricate designs, intricate engravings, and fascinating stories. I was absolutely blown away by the quality and diversity of the exhibits, which cover everything from ancient coins to contemporary pieces.  Visitors are treated to a feast for the eyes and the mind, as the museum offers both stunning visual displays and informative labels that explain the context and significance of each item. The ambiance is quiet and refined, making it easy to fully immerse yourself in the experience. The service is excellent, with knowledgeable staff on hand to answer any questions and guide you through the collection.  What makes the Mus√©e de la Monnaie truly special is the opportunity to witness the artistry and craftsmanship that goes into creating these miniature works of art. The museum features a workshop where you can watch skilled artisans at work, using traditional techniques to produce beautiful medals and coins.  I cannot find any fault with this museum and would give it a perfect score. My only suggestion would be to offer more interactive exhibits or hands-on activities for children, but this is a minor point. I would highly recommend the Mus√©e de la Monnaie to anyone interested in the history of money, art, or both. It is truly a gem in the heart of Paris.  To the owners and staff of the Mus√©e de la Monnaie, I would like to express my gratitude for the exceptional experience you have created. Your passion for your subject shines through in every detail, and I left feeling inspired and enriched. I would definitely consider returning and hope that others will take the opportunity to discover this hidden gem.

Monnaie de Paris is perfect museum to know about history of money. Located near Pont Neuf is easy to reach this museum. The children also can play with the museum display and how the coins is created. There is also store where the visitors can buy a coins from Monnaie de Paris

This is one of the most underrated sites we visited.  I researched the Conti 11 before arriving to Paris and our visit did not disappoint. There is a lot to see here and it‚Äôs never crowded, we did not visit the exhibition portion as we were tired and pressed for time, but the museum portion was extraordinary.  There are also interactive exhibits which is mainly for kids but my husband and I enjoyed them as well. We went on a Saturday and it was not busy at all really quiet and peaceful, the only downfall was that the windows showing the workshops had no people working in them, I assume this would be even more interesting to see the people working on site. Still very cool. The current exhibit is on until February of 2020, seen some of the artists work online, worth seeing if you have the time, visiting just the museum portion is 10 euros and museum plus exhibit is 12 euros. Classy little gift shop on the way out. Will certainly go back next time. There is a little something for everyone.

We had a bit of a hiccup finding it. It's a shared building (-a restaurant). But all in all, it was a fantastic visit. For people who are interested in history of minting and production of money, this is for you. Let me tell you a little secret: if you're lucky, you'll get to mint your own money and take it home with youüòâ
A Nice and interesting museum of money in an attractive area of Paris. It was also an interesting exhibition on art and money. To visit at least once

Gorgeous museum, very well organized with countless multimedia and interactive displays. Only the boutique is somewhat disappointing as it features only a small fraction of what is available for purchase via the web site.

Really surprised by this museum (and the temporary exhibition as well). Very informative, tons of interesting stuff to learn and artifacts to discover. There is also a worker (engraver) who shows you the process of designing a coin.
Great museum, very interesting and informative.
Wonderful building, great joy for kids and parents with this exhibition.
Very interesting,  a lot of old coins, orders, machines for their manufacture and you can even touch a lot of them.
Interesting museum where you can see how the coins are made. Personally I loved the souvenir shop most.

Came here with an avid collector of coins. Guarded and watched by heavy security, we had our bags checked before admission of entry. Totally worth a visit. Coins available at the time of our visit were world cup 2018 coins, special designs by renowned Jean Paul Gaultier, disney specials, etc. There's a paris monnaie museum across the shop too. Grab some french minted coins as souvenirs, it's worth it.

An interesting museum that shows you how money is made. The initial focus is on coins, but we learn more than just how coins are stamped. We learn about the value money represents, why it holds it. We also learn about how coins can celebrate a famous monarch or memory, or occasion. We see the scientific methods used to stay ahead of the counterfeiters, and the various knowledge of metals and manufacturing that were required. The museum also shows how the technology improved over centuries.
Loved all the informations about how the coins are made. Beautiful place. Don‚Äôt forget your blank ‚Äúflan‚Äù at the entry so you can make your own coin.

An unexpected detour due to rainy weather turned out to be one of the highlight for our trip in Paris. Not crowed, very informative and educational. Good balance of static display and interactive components. The boutique at the end of the tour is a must visit even if you are not a collector. Highly recommend!
A magnificent building on the river side housing a vast museum.
Paris's former mint. It still operational, but it functions primarily as a museum and is home to a collection of many ancient coins.
The place is great for this type of concerts, very good acoustic.
Really nice museum. I was there on a weekend and there was practically no one else around.
I'm very fond of the temporary exhibitions here. Great ones!

Went to visit on a whim as the museum was offering free entry during August including the special exhibition L'Art-gent - really impressed with the quality and range of the art displayed for the exhibition, which together with the permanent exhibit made for a nice afternoon trip. There was no queue, but having prebooked tickets definitely made it easier as we could just walk straight up to the exhibition.
Learned a lot about the making of coins. Very interesting to visit. Friendly staff. But some the directions in the museum is not very clear.
Wonderful boutique, with a great selection! Staff are very friendly and helpful

Got a private tour inside the factory. Very interesting to see. Maybe not all that have the chance, but still to see one of the oldest companies in the world is just something you have to given the opportunity.
good product for collection or gift
These are very old antiquities. Do you know where I can sell them? I have very old coins Please help me sell it
Kiki Smith is a wonderful artist and her exhibition is a presentation of her Dreamworld in a full spectrum of all art media in an amazing space !

An excellent space to visit in Paris, especially if you collect their medallions at other tourist spots around France. Tour their inhouse museum, see how coins are made and of course shop in their boutique for exquisite and expensive collectors coins or a reasonably priced souvenir. Their collections are updated regularly to match current events. Presently Rugby World Cup, Paris 2024, Year of the Dragon. Disappointing that they didn't make a coin specifically for the defending champions SA while featuring France and a few European countries.

The place was interesting if you are into money history. They have some hands on machines you can use which is nice and entertaining. The whole tour won't take more than 1 hr though unless you are so into it so keep that in mind
Beautiful experience and so interesting
